TopicTitle: Video Wednesday: Scott explains rocket physics

Articles.Content: <figure data-orig-width="480" data-orig-height="92" class="tmblr-full"><img data-orig-width="480" data-orig-height="92" src="https://40.media.tumblr.com/87dda5f22121633ebc5ff4dc817129a6/tumblr_inline_npq2vdw82j1rr2wit_540.jpg"/></figure><figure data-url="https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DzLitRxZMsSc" data-orig-height="304" data-orig-width="540" data-provider="youtube" class="tmblr-embed tmblr-full"><iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zLitRxZMsSc?feature=oembed" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="304" width="540"></iframe></figure><p>Many if not all of you have regularly heard expressions such as Ã¢â‚¬Å“TWRÃ¢â‚¬Â, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Delta VeeÃ¢â‚¬Â and Ã¢â‚¬Å“IspÃ¢â‚¬Â, but what do those actually mean? And how can you use them to your advantage like a true rocket scientist?</p><p>Scott Manley explains how these concepts play a role in rocket physics, and shows you how easy it can be to calculate them by hand. This is a very informative video and a must see if you want to discover the rocket scientist in yourself. Still confused? The <a href="http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/forums/45-The-Science-Labs"><b>Science Labs</b></a> on the KSP forums is the place to ask how physics work!<br/></p>
Great choice in the video today. I actually just finished a course in Physics myself, so I actually understand a lot of this stuff now. Buuttt I'll probably just use kerbal engineer still
That is a great video indeed, thanks to scott now I understand the relation between ISP and exhaust velocity.
It's certainly interesting to see it done, but I'm with Scott... I just let Kerbal Engineer do it for me.
Being a "spreadsheet guy" myself, I just love how all the math he did turned out juuuuuust right. Tells me once more this is not only a stupid rocket building game...

I like to know how things work, but I also like software that does the actual work for me.

And as always, I love the little anecdotes:

"Ok ok, metres, feet, pounds, kilos ... but we can agree with seconds, ja?!"
This is delightful material to cover. So much to learn, so much to teach.
